page.title: 07Horticulture in Rookley
page.content: {Andrew Lord writes:}When my grandad retired from Pidford Farm last October he let my Uncle Artie have the 5-acre field behind our houses in Rookley for horticulture. The soil is medium to heavy loam, 9" top soil, 6" sub-soil, and then a thin layer of gravel on clay. First he drained the land with 4"pipes to break the pan (hard layer). Then he ploughed the whole field. Next he turned it with a cultivator. Straw- berries (different varieties - varied cropping) broad beans, and raspberries were planted on 1 acre. Uncle grassed a small paddock for sheep grazing and ponies and a car park. He gave a small piece to us and my Dad built a stable. The remainder was cultivated in spring after the frost and new potatoes were dug in June. Passers-by can buy our fruit and vegetables from a roadside stall just as you drive into Rookley.
